And I’ve had a few,’ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Paterson’s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while ships’ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboat’s radio: ‘Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.‘Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.’There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours – ‘St Kentigern Refloated.’The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coaster’s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

title: leader march 11 2022 2
story: So the Scottish Government remains adamant in its decision to ban creelers from the Clyde for the next two months or so.We#re not talking North Sea trawlers here that can go where in the interim. We#re talking about small family businesses whose livelihoods depend on them setting their creels in the Clyde.Many have invested heavily in their boats and equipment and have no other options available to them but to sit it out.Many employees of Dawnfresh Seafoods were brought to their knees recently after being denied a week#s wages. Our creel fishermen are having to survive  weeks.Financial compensation is a must and government ministers should now make it a priority to offer this. Before irreversible harm is done.Much has already been said about the rallying of our community to come to the aid of the people fleeing their homes in war-torn Ukraine.But we will keep on saying it.This week it was the efforts from our youngest inhabitants that shone through. From collecting donations to making, drawing and writing messages of hope to their European peers.Keep up the good work, everyone.

title: letters march 11 2022 2
story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.    The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..    The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.    Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..    Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.    To keep the ban in place.    Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Duplicity#s original meaning in English has to do with a kind of deception in which true feelings or intentions are hidden behind  words or actions.I wouldn’t blame the children of South Sudanthey just gave up.One third are suffering chronic malnutrition. Half are missing school. Millions are displaced. And none of them have ever known anything but war.One of my colleagues there, a -year-old man, tells me he has never seen peace in his letime. But he has seen hope. He has witnessed the hope our colourful bowls full of maize and beans bring to some of the poorest children on earth.Mary’s Meals feeds more than two million children every school day in  of the world’s poorest countries.Our nutritious meals attract little ones into the classroom, where they can gain an education that gives them hope for the future.We are already reaching around , hungry children in South Sudan, and – with the support of your readers – we can serve our le-changing meals in even more schools. Please visit marysmeals.org.uk to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan aren’t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. It’s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. Given the right conditions however, growth is virtually unstoppable. We see that from the way the grass grows week after week.So what are the churches doing to prevent growth  Are they ploughing the same furrow over and over again or are they looking for fresh ways to cultivate interest It’s not easy butwe resist change it’s going to become even harder.Springtime invites us to take a fresh look at things and sharpen up our prospects for the future. We shouldn’t be afraid to look at things afresh.That’s when we discover new ideas. New ideas bring new le. Let’s be positive about the future.

title: susan to the four on the campbeltown carpet
story: The club held its Ladies# Open Singles on Wednesday March  and, after some great knockout bowls, the semi-finals were decided with Susan Gilchrist playing Fiona Middleton and Jean Miller taking on Roberta Lafferty.The final was contested by Jean and Susan, with Susan coming out on top for the fourth year running with only Covid managing to interrupt her winning run.#Well done to all entrants and congratulations to Susan,# said a club spokesperson.The club will open its green officially on Saturday April . All members old and new are welcome to attend.

title: its all tickety boo in kintyre
story: Figures obtained by the local democracy reporting service under the Freedom of Information Act show that Argyll and Bute Council issued  penalty charge notices in its car parks in Mid Argyll, Kintyre and the Islands during  and .Of those,  – all bar two of them in Inveraray – have yet to be paid.Two of them date from  – one from the Front Street and coffee house car parks in Inveraray and the other in the Lorne Street coach park in Lochgilphead.A further five issued in the Front Street and coffee house car parks in Inveraray during  remain unpaid, along with one each from the Avenue and Fisher Row car parks, also in Inveraray.The other unpaid ticket from  was issued in the Lorne Street parking area in Lochgilphead.The Front Street and coffee house car parks saw by far the most parking tickets given out during the two years, with  in total, while the Avenue was next with .In the nine months after lockdown was imposed in March ,  tickets were issued in Mid Argyll, Kintyre and the Islands by the council.Only three were issued between April and the end of July, the majority of which was spent with the country under travel restrictions.Only one was issued in the first three months of , when travel restrictions were again in place.The total of  makes up less than two per cent of the total of more than , parking tickets issued across Argyll and Bute by the council in  and .More than  per cent of those were handed out in Helensburgh and Lomond.A council spokesperson said: #The council follows standard legal procedures for any unpaid penalty charge notices.#If you have a question about a parking fine, contact argyll-bute.gov.uk forms car-park-fine-enquiry-form.

title: liveargyll invite to bring along a mum for mothers day
story: liveArgyll leisure members can claim a member guest pass online and bring along a loved one for free, to celebrate a happy and healthy Mother#s Day together.The member guest pass allows any liveArgyll leisure member to invite a guest to enjoy a free gym or swim session, or even a fitness class.It should be noted those wishing to go to a fitness class together will need to phone Aqualibrium on   to book in advance.Robert Judge, liveArgyll area operations manager for Kintyre and Islay, said: ‘This Mother#s Day, liveArgyll wants to help you thank the important women in your le and encourage you to spend time together, all while boosting your health and fitness.‘If you’re not a member, there’s still plenty of ways you can join in the fun. We will be running public swimming sessions over the weekend, including our popular Family Fun session – floor raised – on Sunday from .pm to .pm, or you could book yourselves in for one of our fitness classes.#However you decide to celebrate, we wish you a happy Mother#s Day and look forward to seeing you.’Visit liveargyll mothers-day-guest-pass to request your member guest pass.

title: jake at the double
story: The early pace was set by Stuart MacBrayne, playing his first competition for some time, with a creditable nett .This was equalled in the very next match by Willie Ralston, who coped well with the conditions but couldn#t match the inward half of Stuart to sit second.The early pace-setters were soon to be joined at the top by young Jake MacMillan as he managed to produce a great run in the last five holes to pip Stuart by the better inward half and take his second title in a row.#Well done to all who played and huge thanks to head greenkeeper Jonathan Barbour and assistant Campbell MacBrayne for turning the course out in immaculate condition for the time of year,# said a club spokesperson.Result:  Jake MacMillan - ,  Stuart MacBrayne - ,  Willie Ralston -,  Lee Mathieson - ,  Stevie Garrett -,  Jim Williamson - .Lowest gross score on the day went to Lee Mathieson with a cracking .

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: line-duty-watch-exclusive-ac-12-reunion
story: Martin Compston, Vicky McClure and Adrian Dunbar are reuniting with the writer of the show Jed Mercurio for a "one-off" reunion event in aid of Ardgowan Hospice, where Martin is a patron.The trio, who have been nicking "bent coppers" on screen for a decade, will get together on March  in Port Glasgow Town Hall, close to Martins home in Greenock.All proceeds from the live event will help the local hospice continue its le-changing work in the community.----------------------------The exclusive video will only be available to our subscribers.You can pay as little as £ for your first month and that fee will go directly to Martins favourite charity, Ardgowan Hospice.To sign up, visit our subscribe page here and take advantage of our latest amazing offers.Our exclusive recording of the event will be available to subscribers HERE from Thursday March .For those who already subscribe, you will also receive exclusive access to the video.Subscriptions can be cancelled at any time.If you would like to make a further donation to Ardgowan Hospice, you can do so HERE.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-welcome-back-spectators-popular-easter-saturday-raceday
story: The Betway Easter Saturday, featuring the Queens Cup, is one of the highlights of the sporting calendar in East Lothian and itshas been widely anticipated by racing enthusiasts and those in search of a great day out over the holiday weekend.With racing and entertainment, the East Lothian track will host about , racing fans, who will be able to enjoy an afternoon of racing, street food stalls and ious food and drink options throughout.Easter Saturday, with the highlight the £, Queens Cup, received the royal seal of approval from the Queen herself and will be the feature race of the day.Musselburgh is also delighted to welcome back the team from ITV, who will be covering four races live on ITV Racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: "We are all delighted to welcome our racing fans back to the course."We haven’t been able to allow race-goers to Easter Saturday for the past two years, and as its one of our major flagship races of the year, we are thrilled to provide a destination for couples, friends, families and groups looking for an Easter get-together with a dference."Chad Yeomans, Betway’s head of communications and PR, added: "The Betway Easter Saturday fixture is a great meeting that in  will see theof racing fans to Musselburgh Racecourse."The Betway Queen’s Cup is the feature race on the card and is a great staying handicap, while the Betway Holyrood Handicap promises a competitive dash over five furlongs."Youngsters  and under get free entry to the event when accompanied by a paying adult. There will be a dedicated kids zone, including theof the popular Easter Bunny, free game stalls, free fairground rides for all ages and free face painting.Tickets for the race meetings are on sale now, with an advanced adult offer available to purchase until midnight on April , to save £pp.For the full range of ticket information, visit musselburgh-racecourse tickets easter-saturday---

title: work-start-dunbar-uniteds-new-stand
story: Work is due to start at the club’s New Countess Park within a matter of weeks, ahead of the -seater stand being put in place there.The club hopes that the stand will be ready for the start of the new East of Scotland Football Leagueseason kicking off later this summer.Fans have increasingly got behind Kevin Haynes’ team, who currently sit th out of  teams in the Premier Division, the top flight of the EoSFL, this season.The club enjoyed a memorable debut in the Scottish Cup this season, defeating Broxburn Athletic and Camelon Juniors before losing out to Lothian Thistle Hutchison Vale in the second round.Stuart Robertson, the club’s chairman, said: “It is unbelievable.“We have almost quadrupled our gate income from times before Covid, which is a big testament to how the community has got behind us this season.“We have made a huge effort as a board to be more inclusive.“The Scottish Cup has been helpful and created a buzz.“We had nearly , people to those matches as part of the Scottish Cup campaign.”Work has gone on in the background for a number of years to see a stand erected down the western touchline at New Countess Park.Planning permission is already in place and Mr Robertson confirmed that an order for the -seater stand had now been placed.Local firm AG Thomson will carry out the groundwork before the stand is in place in time for the new season.The club’s chairman took time to praise the community, who had once again got behind the club with about £, raised through a sponsor-a-seat campaign.He said: “I think that New Countess Park is already a top-end facility in the region but this makes it stand out as the best in the region.“There are better in the league, like Linlithgow Rose, but certainly not in East Lothian.“It is all about seeing the other clubs improving all the time and we want to be part of it.“As well as having got the SFA licence last year, this was the next step for the board.“A lot of our fans cannot stand for two hours and hopefully this adds to a really strong following we have got this season.”Eve Coaches, which is the club’s shirt sponsor, has also agreed a -year sponsorship deal on the new stand.The season is due to come to an end on May , when Dunbar head for Tynecastle, but Mr Robertson revealed there were already “high-profile friendlies in the pipeline” to mark the completion of the new stand ahead of the beginning of the   campaign.

title: young-haddington-footballers-send-kits-nigeria
story: A second shipment of training kit, match strips and football boots has been donated by players and families from Haddington Athletic’s youth section.Nandom Domyil, a striker in Nigeria, attended the club’s Whittingehame Drive facility earlier this month as the kit was packed up ready to be sent to his homeland.Nandom also took on the role of guest coach as he put the Hi Hi’s  squad through their paces.The donations are being sent to Greatway Academy Football Club in Lagos – a club previously represented by Nandom and now a youth partner of Haddington Athletic.Nandom, , recently enrolled in a master’s degree at Heriot-Watt University.He said: “I have come to Scotland to pursue my studies and I am only too happy to help Haddington in this way as a thank you for the generosity of the parents and players of the club.“I also want to continue playing football during my stay and am actively seeking a club to join.”

title: cockenzie-port-seton-kids-receive-jubilee-coin
story: The major jubilee celebrations will begin on June  and continue through the weekend until June .Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council announced that, thanks to the generosity of local iniduals and organisations, everyone aged  and under living in the area will receive a diecast commemorative coin.To register to receive the coin, residents should fill out a form at spanglefish cockenzieandportsetoncommunity news.aspNames must be received by March  to ensure they are included in the order.

title: north-berwick-schoolgirls-finish-second-investment-contest
story: Keira Maynard, Bethan Ryan and Marcia Callander represented the school in the Growing Future Assets Competition, designed to encourage more women into the industry and foster new talent.They faced stf competition from schools across the country, eventually finishing second in the - category behind Lochaber High School from Fort William.The S girls were delighted at their achievement and all the experience they gained as a result of the competition.They said: “We really enjoyed getting an insight into the world of investment and are inspired to continue to find out more.“Working closely with our mentor Amanda was massively helpful she supported us with the financial aspect of the competition and gave great presentation tips, which will give us a competitive edge in our future careers.“The Growing Future Assets Competition has given us unparalleled knowledge we otherwise wouldn’t have had, and we would encourage young people curious about business and finance careers to get involved in the future.”For their efforts, they won £ for the school and £ vouchers for themselves.Hannah Fox, business education teacher at North Berwick High School, shared in their delight and said that the girls had gained a valuable insight into the investment industry.She said: “The competition offers more than a chance to gain an insight into the investment industry via task completion it opens doors to valuable industry mentors and opportunities for work place visits.“It is genuinely the most valuable educational competition I’ve worked on and would not hesitate to recommend it to educational peers.”

title: memories-musselburghs-manufacturing-past
story: The initiative – ‘Made in Musselburgh: Memories of Industry in the Honest Toun’ – is aimed at preserving knowledge of an important part of the town’s past.An open drop-in event will be held at Stuart House, Eskmills, on Wednesday, March , from am to pm, when residents will hear how they can get involved.A project spokesperson said that the manufacturing industry was a prominent employer in Musselburgh for many years.Brunton’s Wire Mill made wire for musical instruments and ropes.During the First World War, the Air Ministry relied on the company for the manufacture of aeroplane wires.Production was again focused on military manufacturing during the Second World War, including bomb slings, aeroplane cables and fittings, ropes for many purposes, and whip aerials.In the s and s, the firm continued to specialise in aircraft wings and fittings.One growing area of supply at this time was in bridge ropes, and the company made all of the wire ropes used in the construction of the Forth Road Bridge, and the suspension ropes for the Humber Bridge.In February , Brunton’s closed, ending  years of wire manufacture in the town.J  W Stuart Mills became a world leader in the fishing net industry, with sales and repair facilities in North America, Europe and Australia.Colonel James Paterson, local to Musselburgh, invented and patented in  the first machine capable of tying knots for the manufacture of fishing nets.When he died, his company and patents for knot-tying machines were bought by J.W. Stuart, who established a factory for the manufacture of fishing nets on the banks of the River Esk.Inveresk Paper Mill was another of Musselburgh’s past industries, built by Alex Cowan and Sons of Valleyfield in .The paper manufacturer specialised in fine writing, printing and art papers.The mill closed in  and was mostly demolished.The council-operated John Gray Centre in Haddington, which holds local archives, and the European Ethnological Research Centre , from the University of Edinburgh, are working to record the memories of local people.Mark Mulhern, senior research fellow at the EERC, explained: “Hearing from the folk of Musselburgh about their memories of its industrial manufacturing past will greatly enrich our understanding of the Honest Toun.”Ruth Fyfe, archivist with East Lothian Council, said: “We have a fantastic collection of images in the archives relating to the wire, net and paper mills in Musselburgh so this is a great opportunity to come along and see them.“We’re excited to be part of the project. ”part of the project. The recordings will be available to the public and preserved in our archives for generations to come so this really is a chance to be involved in making Musselburgh’s history."

title: new-gym-set-macmerry-industrial-estate
story: East Lothian Council has granted planning permission for the units to be built south of the A.Crossfit Haddington, Hickory Food and Edinburgh Plant Hire are set to take the premises.Planning permission is in place for one of the units to be used as a fitness centre, while the other two are designated as being for storage and distribution.: Tranent gym plans given the green lightA car park with  spaces, and a further three spaces for disabled users, will be created.There were no objections to Merryfield IC Ltd’s proposals.

title: musselburgh-store-boss-argues-vaping-display-ban
story: Dan Brown, , owner of Pinkie Farm Convenience Store at Moray Way and president of the Scottish Grocers’ Federation , fears that the proposals will hamper efforts to help smokers kick their habit, as well as hit trade in local shops.He said that potential curbs on displaying vaping products in stores would be “bad news” for the campaign to make the region smoke-free and healthier.Mr Brown, a Musselburgh resident, is also concerned the proposals would hit his business and is supporting calls for them to be dropped.A consultation on tightening rules around the advertising and promotion of vaping products includes a move to outlaw in-store promotional displays.The SGF is arguing that any such ban risks setting back the health agenda by “hiding a proven route for smokers to quit”.While SGF members, including Mr Brown, sell both cigarettes and e-cigarettes, they say that they are committed to playing their part in improving health outcomes by reducing tobacco sales and replacing them with sales of vapour products.He said: “From both a business and public health point of view, restricting vaping products makes absolutely no sense.“These need to be visible in-store so that retailers can help customers to find the right kind of product.“The marketing and the display of vapes go together to help raise awareness of these products.“If we are serious about achieving a tobacco-free generation then we must recognise the important role vaping can play.”SGF is urging shopkeepers across Edinburgh and the Lothians to make their views known to the Government by responding to its consultation, which closes on April .Dr John Lee, SGF head of public affairs, claimed: “The proposal to ban the in-store promotion of vaping products is bad news for the drive to make Scotland smoke-free by .“It’s also potentially harmful for the local economy by financially penalising the region’s convenience stores, whose staff do a fantastic job serving their communities and are committed to selling vaping products responsibly.”In the Scottish Government’s online consultation, Maree Todd MSP, Minister for Public Health, Women’s Health and Sport, stated: “While we continue to work towards addressing historic trends of high smoking rates, we are aware that technological and cultural advancements can bring about new public health concerns.“The emergence of vaping products, including electronic cigarettes, as an alternative to tobacco is one such concern.“The full impact of their long-term use is not yet known and could have a negative impact on public health in years to come.“Reducing exposure to the advertising and promotion of vape products is the best way to protect non-smokers, young people and children from being enticed to experiment with these products.“Vaping products should only be used as a tool to help people stop smoking tobacco. They are not a lestyle accessory.”Access the consultation at gov.scot publications tight ening-rules-advertising-promoting-vaping-products-consultation-paper- pages

title: leuchie-house-takes-ownership-new-holiday-cottage
story: The North Berwick-based charity provides respite breaks for people living with neurological conditions and the new addition will expand these facilities further.Denis Duncan House, on Manse Road, Dirleton, will offer guests an accessible holiday cottage that sleeps six people.The property has two fully accessible disability beds, meaning guests can enjoy holidays with independence and spend quality time together with family and carers.Mark Bevan, Leuchie House CEO, said: “We are determined to do more for more people, not only within Leuchie but beyond our walls, and Denis Duncan House gives us that opportunity to allow families to enjoy some quality time and independence.“We are extremely grateful to the Lin Berwick Trust for making the cottage available to us.”One-week stays at Denis Duncan House are available from £, and can be booked via den isduncanhouse or by calling the Leuchie bookings team on  .

title: musselburgh-army-cadets-recruiting-new-youngsters
story: The youth group, which is sponsored by the Ministry of Defence, aims to teach youngsters aged - a wide range of subjects, from military skills to first aid and navigation.The cadets meet every Monday and Wednesday evening, pm to pm, at their Goose Green Place headquarters.Anyone interested in joining should go along on the night.

title: another-149-new-homes-wallyford-now-offered-sale
story: Housebuilder Taylor Wimpey East Scotland said it had launched phase two of its Ravensheugh development following the "success" of phase one.Interested homebuyers can book an appointment to chat to the local sales executive and browse the selection of two, three and four bedroom homes available.A "range of options for first-time buyers and growing families", was highlighted by the company, with prices starting from £, for the Drummond four-bedroom detached home.The wider St Clements Wells masterplan has seen a new Wallyford Primary School opened at Futures Way, while a new secondary school is currently being built.A local centre and community woodland, along with new foot and cycle connections to Wallyford and the village’s train station, are also proposed.East Lothian Council, as the roads authority, has taken over the main spine road through the development.A dining area at one of the new homesKirsty McGill, sales and marketing director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: "Our Ravensheugh development continues to go from strength to strength, and phase one, which provides  of our new homes, are now fully reserved, almost complete and the final homeowners are in the process of moving in to finalise this part of the development."St Clements Wells is a new and growing community that is already creating a lovely to place to call home for a wide iety of buyers."Phase two of our Ravensheugh development allows us to continue to play our part in the delivery of the masterplan vision for this area."This phase will now offer buyers a similar mix of two and three bedroom homes to those that we built previously, as well as a larger choice of four bedroom detached homes to appeal to growing families."She added: "At the moment, all we ask is that prospective buyers book an appointment with us to ensure that we can maintain our strict Covid-secure protocols to keep everyone safe."Video calls to find out more about the homes available are also still available for those customers who prefer this approach and these can be booked by calling    or emailing ravensheugh@taylorwimpeyNormal working hours are .am-.pm, Thursday to Monday.Visit taylorwimpey ravensheugh to find out more about the development.

title: north-berwick-harbour-trust-looking-harbour-helpers
story: A post on Facebook said: “We are looking for volunteers who would be happy to help out with tasks such as painting, weeding, and other things to improve the aesthetic of the harbour and, over time, improve the state of the state of repair.”The Harbour Trust consists of volunteers who lease the land from East Lothian Council and are responsible for its maintenance and upkeep.Those interested in helping can contact the group on Facebook.

title: local-group-ignite-peoples-creativity-new-project
story: MADE in East Lothian is launching a programme to engage the community in a new creative project." alt"East Lothian Courier: The Story Wagon offers story-telling and creative writing for all ages and is one of the highlights at MADE in East Lothianrsquos Open Day " class"editor-image"Entitled ‘Creative Connections’, the six-month project is possible thanks to funding from the National Lottery Community Fund and will highlight the fundamental aims of MADE in East Lothian to support local makers and crafters, and promote its ethos of make, create and reuse.The project launches with an open day next Saturdayat the MADE Arts Hub in Haddington.Fiona Lambert, director and co-founder of MADE in East Lothian, said: “We’ve achieved a lot in six years and hope to develop even further.“The aim of this year’s project is to spread the word, ignite people’s personal creativity, and demonstrate how a resource like MADE in East Lothian can benefit the whole community, especially in protecting the environment and benefiting people’s mental health and wellbeing.“We also hope that the ideas board at the open day will generate ideas for a feasibility study to ascertainthe Hardgate premises can be purchased for redevelopment into a sustainable community arts space for the whole of East Lothian.”The open day will feature storytelling from The Story Wagon, and demonstrations including recycled paper-making, how to make felt tip pen beads, and upcycling techniques.There will also be an ideas board and an exhibition of past artwork, with future events planned throughout the summer.MADE in East Lothian, based on Haddington’s Hardgate and getting ready to celebrate its sixth year, also offers a series of tutored creative art workshops every Saturday, ranging from jewellery-making to mixed media techniques, with eight free tutored workshops being offered throughout the summer as part of the ‘Creative Connections’ project.The programme of events will also engage the many makers and artists in East Lothian, whose unique hand-made products can be purchased online or in the MADE Arts Hub gallery.MADE in East Lothian is a Community Interest Company , which means that all profits are reinvested to benefit the community.For more details, go to www.madeineastlothian.orgThere will also be an ideas board and an exhibition of past artwork, with future events planned throughout the summer.MADE in East Lothian, a social enterprise, is getting ready to celebrate its sixth year since being formed.The group, based on Haddington’s Hardgate, also offers a series of tutored creative art workshops every Saturday, ranging from jewellery-making to mixed media techniques, with eight free tutored workshops being offered throughout the summer as part of the ‘Creative Connections’ project.The programme of events will also engage the many makers and artists in East Lothian, whose unique hand-made products can be purchased online or in the MADE Arts Hub gallery.MADE in East Lothian is a Community Interest Companywhich means that all profits are reinvested to benefit the community.For more details, go to www.madeineastlothian.org

title: mum-complete-15-mile-trek-aid-epilepsy-charity
story: Rachel Cockburn will walk from her home in Dunbar to Haddington next Sundayin aid of Young Epilepsy.The -mile trek is to thank the charity for its support of Rachel’s daughter Amelia, who has epilepsy.The condition, which can affect anyone at any age, is a disorder of the brain in which there is a tendency to have recurring seizures.An epileptic seizure results from a sudden electrical discharge in the brain that causes changes in sensation, behaviour or consciousness.Rachel told the Courier it had been “a bit of a rocky road” in terms of medication but she had received support from hospitals and charities.She said: “I would just like to show my appreciation for what they are doing for my daughter and other people as well.”Amelia was just three years old when she was diagnosed with the condition.Mum-of-two Rachel said: “She had full-on seizures.“It is quite hard to diagnose until you actually get the ECG [electrocardiogram] scan done at the hospital. It was quite a struggle over the years and it is a process of trying to get the right medication and get the seizures under control.”Amelia, who is now , will join her mum on part of the walk as Rachel, , sets off from Belhaven Parish Church at .am, through West Barns before heading on to Foxlake Adventures. Sister Christina, , will also take part.She will then continue through East Linton before reaching the finish line at Haddington’s Corn Exchange.Sally Brighton, director of fundraising at the charity, told the Courier: “Epilepsy can be one of the most frightening, lonely and misunderstood conditions a child can experience.Living in this unpredictable world takes its toll on a child’s physical and mental health.“Thank you, Rachel and Amelia, for raising essential funds. The money you raise will help us make sure children with epilepsy aren’t missing out on their childhood.”To make a donation, go to justgiving fundrais ing rachel-cockburn

title: north-berwick-community-plant-400-trees-queens-canopy
story: The community planting day took place at North Berwick Trust’s park, on the town’s southern edge, with volunteers from North Berwick in Bloom, Sustaining North Berwick, Bass Rock Community Group and North Berwick Rotary Club all coming out to help.The planting comes as part of The Queen’s Green Canopy, an initiative set up to celebrate the Queen’s platinum jubilee by increasing and protecting native tree cover.The trees – including silver birch, rowan and hazel – were planted along the western edge of the field to form a shelter belt and provide habitats for wildle. They were grown by Alba Trees, based near Gladsmuir, and donated by the Woodland Trust.Volunteers will nowon the first Saturday of each month to look after the trees, cut the grass and provide enough water and care for them to survive.

title: lollipop-man-brings-joy-children-new-knitted-friend
story: Stewart Thompson, Preston Tower Primary School’s Preston Road campus patrol officer, has been praised by parents for his service to school children in the area.Stewart and his companion, knitted by his partner Agnes Goodsir, sport matching unorm, hats and lollipop sticks.One Facebook user said: “My son walks the long way round just so he can cross with Stewart – he’s the best.”

title: gardening-column-furnishing-outdoor-living-room
story: Garden furniture is an important purchase but how do you make sure you’re getting best value for your money This month, we’re considering timber, metal and rattan furniture, and suggesting what you should look for in making this decision.Timber furnitureThe first consideration in choosing wooden garden furniture is always the timber that it’s made from.Softwoods – for example pine – grow rapidly and are therefore the cheapest wood but generally don’t last as long as the slower-growing hardwoods such as mahogany or teak.Whatever timber you choose, it’s important to check that it carries the FSC mark. This confirms that the timber has been grown in sustainable forests where young trees are replanted to replace the mature trees as they’re harvested.This is particularly important with hardwoods – unfortunately, there are still foreign governments who allow their rainforests to be cleared without replacing the trees that are so important for our global environment.Being a natural, organic material, part of the beauty of timber is seeing it mature. It will absorb water when it rains and dry out when the sun shines and the fibres of the timber will change, expanding and contracting as moisture levels y.Customers often worry when they see this movement but it is natural and what you’re seeing is simply part of the ageing process that all living organisms undergo. If it doesn’t affect the structural integrity of your furniture, there’s no cause for concern!The lespan of timber furniture ies greatly. Some pine benches may last a few years whilst a good teak piece can last in excess of  years. As with all furniture, much will depend on how you care for it, ensuring it doesn’t sit for prolonged periods in water, protecting it from the worst of the elements, especially over winter.Treating wooden furniture is often an aesthetic choice, whilst many customers prefer to see the timber mature naturally.Metal FurnitureAmongst the most common metals used in garden furniture are cast iron, stainless steel and aluminium. Whilst each metal may y in quality , you’ll generally find that cast iron is cheapest, with aluminium the most expensive.Cast iron tends to be very heavy and has a ‘chunky’ look, reminiscent of lovely old-fashioned garden furniture. Its weight makes it very stable in the garden but it does require maintenance to prevent corrosion as that could eventually weaken the structure.Stainless steel is lighter than cast iron and is valued for its strength, robustness, durability and resistance to corrosion. It’s often used as the frame of the furniture rather than the finished, outer coat.Although generally the most expensive, aluminium is an ideal metal for garden furniture. Lightweight, strong, robust and long-lasting, it withstands the elements well and requires minimal maintenance.Rattan or wicker FurnitureSynthetic rattan or wicker has overtaken the use of their natural equivalents because they are longer-lasting, easier to maintain and available in a wide range of colours, textures and shapes.There’s an enormous iation in quality and price but a quick look at the warranty is usually a good initial indication of what you’re being offered.Another factor affecting the price of rattan furniture is the size and shape of the weave.There are three main profiles – flat, half-round and round – with the flat generally being cheapest and the round being dearest.Depending on the look you want, the half-round and round profile will offer texture and depth to your furniture, whilst the flat weave offers a smoother, more even surface.Rattan can fade and deteriorate from the UV rays in the sunlight and the UV warranty of the product is also an important indication of quality.WarrantyNow you’ve chosen your perfect furniture, take a moment to check how the manufacturer recommends you care for your furniture – it is an investment and certainly worth taking care of!Remember that furniture can be made from a combination of materials and each component – for example, the frame and cushions – are likely to have dferent warranties.Finally…In this column we’re only able to offer a quick overview of some of the things to look for when choosing your garden furniture, but staff in reputable garden centres will be able to advise you in more detail and help you choose the best solution for you and your family.The internet is a handy way to start considering your options and indeed you’re very welcome to have a preview of our garden furniture online at merryhattonHowever, we strongly recommend that you always see the products in-store to get a feel for the comfort and quality before buying.That’s the best way to make an informed choice – and avoid an expensive mistake!More information is available at merryhatton

title: three-venues-confirmed-covid-booster-jags
story: The vaccination will be available by appointment to those aged  and over, immunosuppressed people and those living in care homes.People will be invited as they become eligible from about  weeks after their last booster.Musselburgh Primary Care Centre is open from .am to .pm, Monday to Friday, and vaccinations will be given by appointment only.Haddington’s Corn Exchange is open for vaccinations – appointment or drop-in – also between .am and .pm, Monday to Friday.A drop-in service is available to those aged  and over who require first or second Covid jags or a first booster.Children aged - can be vaccinated between the same times on Saturdays and Sundays by appointment only.Finally, vaccinations by appointment only will be given at North Berwick’s Edington Hospital from Monday, .am-.pm, Monday-Friday.Krista Clubb, primary care vaccination service manager, said: “The spring booster will improve your level of protection and is the best way to protect your health and those around you.“Letters will be sent out to people eligible in the coming weeks to invite them to come along to an appointment.”

title: important-milestone-reached-neart-na-gaoithe-plans
story: The first turbine blades for the Neart na Gaoithedevelopment have arrived in the port of Dundee.NnG is under construction  kilometres off the Fe coastline and km north of Torness.The windfarm will come on shore at Thorntonloch beach, to the south-east of Dunbar, before two buried cables will cross farmland for about  kilometres to the grid connection point at Crystal Rig windfarm in the Lammermuir Hills.An important step forward has been taken in the plans for an offshore windfarm The offshore windfarm consists of  turbine towers which will be assembled in Dundee before being placed alongside turbine blades on a specialist wind turbine installation vessel which will transport them to, and install them, at the site of the offshore windfarm.The first turbines will be operational in time for the windfarm to begin generating power next year, with completion scheduled for .NnG, jointly owned by EDF Renewables and ESB, will have a capacity of about  MegaWatts .

title: tesco-clubcard-holders-can-claim-mothers-day-treat
story: In perfect time for Mothers Day, Tesco has shared how customers and users of the Clubcard Reward Partners can get exclusive discounts to a range of exciting activities. From visiting historic grounds to a relaxing spa getaway and even discounts on loads of great products. Soyoure a holder of the Tesco Clubcard then you are in luck as you could treat your loved one and save money too. " alt"East Lothian Courier: Mothers Day is March . " class"editor-image"Mothers Day is March .If you or someone you love are a history buff then you can use your rewards card to save money on some days at iconic English Heritage locations. From Hadrians Wall, Stonehenge, or the medieval Dover Castle to name just a few.Plus even better shoppers can get one complimentary adult entry with one full paying adult when booking online and entering the promotion code at checkout, as well as saving % in the on-site café.And theres no need to worryyou cant decide which great site to visit, instead, you exchange your Clubcard vouchers for an English Heritage annual membership.The pass offers you unlimited access to castles, gardens, historic houses, abbeys, and more for the rest of the year, with a £ savingIf you rather have a relaxing day then Tesco has that covered with vouchers offered with SpaSeekers. At SpaSeekers you can choose from one of their many locations across the country and enjoy great food, gorgeous setting, pampering, and more. You can even buy some extra treats for yourself too, with the reward points, from at-home cocktail kits or some luxury jewellery from Goldsmiths. The choices are endless with the Tesco Clubcard and its a great way to save some hard-earned money.

title: brunton-country-music-orchestra
story: An afternoon with Royal Scottish National Orchestra is a treat for mums this Sunday, March , at pm.After a three year break, the orchestra s to The Brunton with one of the greatest of all symphonies, Tchaikovskys th, with its fate theme surrounded by rich music. Principal bassoon David Hubbard offers one piece of virtuoso fun and Elgars wistful romance, and Kellen Gray conducts.Mothering Sundayis the midweek movie on Wednesday, April . It tells the story of how on a warm spring day in , house maid and foundling Jane Fairchildfinds herself alone on Mothers Day. Her employers, Mr and Mrs Niven , are out and she has the rare chance to spend an afternoon of abandon with her secret lover, Paul , the boy from the manor house nearby. He Janes long-term love despite the fact that hes engaged to be married to another woman, a childhood friend and daughter of his parents friends. But events that neither can foresee will change the course of Janes le forever.Other attractions at The Brunton include Nashville Live - a celebration of country music and the stories behind the hits, performed in the style of a live radio broadcast. The show features music from golden greats such as Johnny Cash, Willie Nelson and Dolly Parton, through to the contemporary platinum selling sounds of Garth Brooks and Dixie Chicks. The classic solos, duets and group harmonies are delivered by a cast of performers alongside a stellar live band fronted by British Country Musician of the Year , Luke Thomas, tomorrow, Friday, March .Direct from Londons west end, the Chicago Blues Brothers and their  piece band bring their all singing, all dancing hit parade with the greatest movie anthems of all time this Saturday, March . The concert features songs from Footloose, A Star is Born, Dirty Dancing, The Greatest Showman and the Full Monty as well as much loved Blues Brothers classics.Produced by Scottish Theatre Producers, in association with Beacon Arts Centre, Stand By, written by a former police officer, also takes place this Saturday, March . Audiences are asked to wear single-earpiece headphones, as police officers do, to tell this urgent story in a multi-sensory way. Four officers sit in a riot van. Called out to a domestic dispute, which may turn violent, they are on stand by - waiting to enter a flat where a man is wielding a samurai sword. The audience waits with them, experiencing the relationships, forged through the stress of the job and the turmoil of being caught between following orders and protecting themselves.A theatrical homage to Edith Piaf - one of Frances most endearing icons - can be enjoyed at The Brunton next Thursday, March . The show stars award-winning songwriter Christine Bovill who has toured throughout Europe and the Far East with her self-penned homage to the Little Sparrow, appearing on BBC Newsnight and on BBC Radio s series, Soul Music. During her Edinburgh Fringe sell-out run at the Famous Speigeltent, she realised a lelong dream when she shared the stage with Charles Dumont, great friend of Piaf and, most famously, composer of Non, Je ne Regrette Rien. They performed several songs together to close the show. PIAF was awarded the Fringe laurels for total sell out show  and  with five star reviews.The legendary record label Sun Records, famed for Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, Johnny Cash, Roy Orbison, Carl Perkins, Rufus Thomas, will come to le, live on stage on Friday, April . Musical visionary, Sam Phillips’ Memphis studio produced hundreds of hits that would influence the world of music for generations to come such as That’s Alright Mama, Great Balls of Fire, I Walk the Line, Whole Lotta Shakin’, Bear Cat, Blue Suede Shoes and Good Rockin’ Tonight. Rehearsed in an exact replica of the Sun Studios, featuring musical instruments of the era, the concert, which takes the audience back to the birthplace of rock and roll, features a multi-talented cast of singers and musicians.Irish legends The Fureys, who have been entertaining audiences for  years,to the Musselburgh stage for another night of music, songs and stories on Thursday, April . They sing their timeless classics including I Will Love You, When You Were Sweet , The Green Fields of France and The Old Man as well as songs from their new CD The Times They Are A Changing.Full information about all the events can be found at www.thebrunton.Tickets can be purchased directly through The Brunton’s website or via the box office telephone number    which is open from Monday to Saturday, am to pm.

title: plans-new-snack-van-longniddry-bents-car-park-no-2
story: The mobile snack van would be sited at Longniddry Bents Car Park Number  under the plans with East Lothian Council.The planning application is the latest in a number of proposals for coastal car parks submitted to the local authority.Catherine King’s proposals outline hopes to serve “mid-morning snacks, lunch treats and afternoon snacks” throughout the year.A menu shows plans for cakes, coffee, confectionary and soft drinks, with ice cream on the menu in the summer.Salad boxes and filled rolls could be served up when the business is established.It is hoped the snack van would be operational from am to pm through the summer and finishing at pm in the winter.A litter policy is also included with the application, which the council hopes to determine by the middle of May.Bins will be placed daily and emptied at home, with no unnecessary plastic or wrappings.Customers will also be encouraged to bring their own cup with Ms King planning beach cleans infor free coffee and cake events.

title: record-number-school-leavers-east-lothian-going-higher-education
story: East Lothian Council saw its ‘positive destination’ figures for students leaving schools rise to . per cent, above the national average of . per cent.But while the percentage of school leavers going into jobs remained well above the national average, with more than  per cent in work compared to . per cent nationally, it was the increase in those going into higher education which stood out.In  to , it was reported that  per cent of students went on to university from East Lothian schools however, last year the figure rose to . per cent, bringing it in line with the Scottish average.The number of care-experienced leavers reaching a positive destination after leaving school last year was also above the national average, with nearly  per cent in the county compared to  per cent nationally.The Scottish Government describes a positive destination as “higher education and further education, training, voluntary work, employment and activity agreements”.More than  per cent of care-experienced school leavers went into further education – compared to just . per cent two years earlier.The county also saw the number of leavers with additional support needs finding a positive destination reach  per cent – one per cent above the national average.A report to the council’s education committee earlier this week highlighted the work done through foundation apprenticeships provided through East Lothian Works with business partners and schoolsA range of initiatives and changes introduced to support young people, including a common school day to allow inter school co-operation  and key worker support for apprentices, continued to support them.A spokesperson for education told a virtual meeting of the committee that working with partners to continue apprenticeship programmes had continued throughout the Covid- crisis.He said: “Even during the pandemic, because these were our foundation apprenticeships with our providers, miraculously, we were able to provide work placements digitally.“Our pupils on those exciting pathways graduated and got those qualications.”Nicola McDowell, the councils head of education, welcomed the positive destination performance.She said: “The last few years have been challenging from an economic and educational perspective due to Covid-, which is why I am so pleased to see the data confirm that East Lothian’s young people are being well supported to make positive steps into the world of work, education and training.“Working with our partners and schools, East Lothian Works has transformed how we operate to respond in a way that meets the needs of our learners and school leavers, giving them the tools and opportunities that they need to succeed.“We will continue to develop programmes and initiatives that make sure all of our learners have access to the support that they need during their time in school and beyond.”

title: musselburgh-businessman-sponsors-county-snooker-star-ross-muir---hopes-inspire-love-sport
story: Former boxer Alex Brown, of High Street-based Ideal Flooring Solutions, is delighted to support the former Musselburgh Grammar School pupil with funds for his travel and other overheads.Ross, , who lives on the town’s Edinburgh Road, said that it would be “a long-term” partnership, with the hope they might get involved in community-based activities in the future.In the first round of the BetVictor Gibraltar Open today , Ross will play Mark Williams, the Welsh snooker player and three-times world champion, at pm.Alex said: “This match for Ross against Mark Williams will be shown on Eurosport and it’s a great opportunity for Ross, who is the only professional snooker player I’m aware of from East Lothian, to show off his skills.“I feel a win for Ross against Mark Williams, a three-time world champion, would be a brilliant achievement and inspire young people from East Lothian to take up the sport.”Alex is also sponsoring Ross in his quest to qualy for the World Snooker Championship next month.Three qualying rounds will be held at the English Institute of Sport in Sheffield, with the championship being staged at the Crucible Theatre.Alex said: “All of us at Ideal Flooring Solutions wish Ross all the best for both tournaments.”Ross said: “It is absolutely fantastic to have Alex onboard.“He is someone who is very passionate about sport and the local community. He is a great guy.”He paid tribute to Alex’s fundraising, including his most recent appeal to help people in war-torn Ukraine.Ross is looking forward to meeting Mark Williams, whom he described as “one of the legends of the sport”, at the BetVictor Gibraltar Open.He said: “Mark was my very first match as a professional when I was  and is a fantastic player.“I’ve not played him for a few years.”Ross said he was working hard with his coach and on the practice table, with qualying for the World Snooker Championship his goal.He highlighted the popularity of snooker in East Lothian with a well-attended exhibition match between two snooker greats – Stephen Hendry and Jimmy White – at The Brunton in Musselburgh last week.A question-and-answer session was also enjoyed.“It was fantastic – everyone loved it,” Ross said, adding that it was hoped that something similar could be organised in the community in the future.Alex is raising £, to support people from Ukraine and has match-funded the first £ himself.Musselburgh resident Jim Cranston, who owns Portobello-based builder Acorn Services, pledged £ to help Alex reach his JustGiving target of £,, which, along with £ in Gt Aid, will go to the Ukraine Humanitarian Appeal.Alex said: “It is very dficult to raise funds, with so many people raising funds, but I’ve managed this with the amazing help of Jimmy Cranston and his we Pauline, my son-in-law Ashley Jones, who gave very generous donations, and many other amazing people who have supported my fundraising for many years.“I feel very strongly about what’s happening in the Ukraine and it’s heartbreaking to watch.“I have thanked every single person directly for each donation.”Go to justgiving crowdfunding monica-brown to support Mr Brown’s appeal.

title: tranent-asda-employee-praised-rushing-aid-unwell-customer
story: Lynette Thomson, who works at the supermarkets Tranent branch, went above and beyond to care for a customer who became suddenly unwell in store while shopping.Lynette rushed to the assistance of the shopper, who had a bad coughing fit, bringing her a chair and a glass of water in a bid to help the pensioner get her breath back.The kind Asda colleague reassured the woman and made her comfortable before continuing with her job once she had been assured that the lady was feeling better.Lynette, who has been working as a front-end colleague in the store since it opened in , said: "I could hear that the woman was unwell and appreciate how uncomfortable it is for anyone during the pandemic to suffer from a coughing fit."I went straight over to seeI could help her and check that she was OK."I am glad that I was able to help."She was very grateful and all she needed was someone to look after her for a wee bit, I was happy to do so."Louise Mercer, Asda service section leader, said: "Lynette is one of the friendliest people I know."She is always willing to help our colleagues and customers."I was not surprised when the customer came to commend Lynette – she is a real star and an asset to our team."

title: wordle-276-march-22-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result. - Wordle  March : Wordle word hints and todays answerIf you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter S and ends with the letter H.It has one vowel.It is used to describe the sound of liquid moving in a container.What is today’s Wordle answer, Tuesday, March  If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now. The Wordle for March  is SLOSH. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.“After all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.“Given this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I’ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.”
